conclusion: Put the boundary MN on the y-axis (x = 0).
The magnetic field exists in the half-plane x ≥ 0, is uniform (B) and perpendicular to the paper.
The equilateral triangle (side a) keeps its orientation while its whole figure translates to the right with a constant velocity v.
At t = 0 the vertex D is on the boundary (D: x = 0).
Let the horizontal shift of the triangle be s = vt (0 ≤ s ≤ a); then C: (s − a, 0) D: (s, 0) E: (s − a/2, −h), h = √3 a /2.
Use Faraday’s law ε = |dΦ / dt| = B |dA_in / dt|, where A_in is the part of the triangular area that has already entered the field.
During an infinitesimal shift ds the only new area that enters the field is the vertical strip of width ds situated just at the boundary x = 0.
dA_in = L(s) ds, where L(s) is the total length of the cross-section of the triangle by the line x = 0.
Determine L(s) for 0 ≤ s ≤ a/2 (apex E is still on the left of the boundary).
The line x = 0 cuts the edges CD (at y = 0) and DE.
For DE: x = s − a/2 t, y = -h t (0 ≤ t ≤ 1) → set x = 0 gives t = 2s/a, y = − 2h s / a.
The two intersection points are (0, 0) and (0, − 2h s / a).
L(s) = 2h s / a for 0 ≤ s ≤ a/2.
Determine L(s) for a/2 ≤ s ≤ a (apex E is already inside the field).
Now x = 0 cuts the edges CD (still at y = 0) and CE.
For CE: x = s − a + (a/2) t, y = −h t → x = 0 gives t = 2(a − s)/a, y = −2h (a − s)/a.
